name: Pythagorean trigonometric identity
explanation: The fundamental identity cos²A + sin²A = 1 relating sine and cosine of the same angle.

name: Sine rule for triangles
explanation: A formula relating the sides and angles of a triangle: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C.

name: Cosine rule for triangles
explanation: A formula relating the sides and angles of a triangle: a² = b² + c² – 2bc cos A.

name: Cosine of difference formula
explanation: The identity cos(A–B) = cos A cos B + sin A sin B expressing cosine of a difference of angles.

name: Cosine of sum formula
explanation: The identity cos(A+B) = cos A cos B – sin A sin B expressing cosine of a sum of angles.

name: Double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A)
explanation: The formula cos 2A = cos²A – sin²A expressing cosine of double an angle.

name: Sine of sum formula
explanation: The identity sin(A+B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B expressing sine of a sum of angles.

name: Sine of difference formula
explanation: The identity sin(A–B) = sin A cos B – cos A sin B expressing sine of a difference of angles.

name: Tangent of sum formula
explanation: The formula tan(A+B) = (tan A + tan B) / (1 – tan A tan B) expressing tangent of a sum of angles.

name: Tangent of difference formula
explanation: The formula tan(A–B) = (tan A – tan B) / (1 + tan A tan B) expressing tangent of a difference of angles.

name: Double angle formula for sine (sin 2A)
explanation: The formula sin 2A = 2 sin A cos A expressing sine of double an angle.

name: Alternative double angle formula for sine
explanation: A variation of the double angle formula for sine expressed as sin 2A = 2 sin A cos A (repeated for emphasis).

name: Alternative double angle formula for cosine
explanation: Equivalent forms of cos 2A such as cos 2A = 2 cos²A – 1 or cos 2A = 1 – 2 sin²A.

name: Double angle formula for tangent
explanation: The formula tan 2A = 2 tan A / (1 – tan² A) expressing tangent of double an angle.

name: Power-reduction formula for cosine squared
explanation: The formula cos²A = ½ (1 + cos 2A) expressing cosine squared in terms of cosine of double angle.

name: Power-reduction formula for sine squared
explanation: The formula sin²A = ½ (1 – cos 2A) expressing sine squared in terms of cosine of double angle.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 cos A cos B
explanation: The identity 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B) + cos(A–B) converting product of cosines into sum of cosines.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 sin A cos B
explanation: The identity 2 sin A cos B = sin(A+B) + sin(A–B) converting product of sine and cosine into sum of sines.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 sin A sin B
explanation: The identity 2 sin A sin B = cos(A–B) – cos(A+B) converting product of sines into difference of cosines.

name: Product-to-sum formula: 2 cos A sin B
explanation: The identity 2 cos A sin B = sin(A+B) – sin(A–B) converting product of cosine and sine into difference of sines.

name: Sum-to-product formula: cos A + cos B
explanation: The identity cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2) expressing sum of cosines as product of cosines.

name: Sum-to-product formula: cos A – cos B
explanation: The identity cos A – cos B = –2 sin((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2) expressing difference of cosines as product of sines.

name: Sum-to-product formula: sin A + sin B
explanation: The identity sin A + sin B = 2 sin((A+B)/2) cos((A–B)/2) expressing sum of sines as product of sine and cosine.

name: Sum-to-product formula: sin A – sin B
explanation: The identity sin A – sin B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A–B)/2) expressing difference of sines as product of cosine and sine.

name: circle construction with given radius
explanation: Drawing a circle precisely using a compass when the radius length is specified.

name: use of straight edge in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a straight edge tool to draw straight lines accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of compass in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles with precision in geometric diagrams.

name: use of ruler in geometric constructions
explanation: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and draw straight lines accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of protractor in geometric constructions
explanation: Using a protractor to measure and construct angles accurately in geometric diagrams.

name: use of set square in geometric constructions
explanation: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines in geometric diagrams.

name: coordinating the plane
explanation: Assigning ordered pairs (x, y) to points in a two-dimensional plane to represent their positions.

name: representation of linear relationships in tabular form
explanation: Organizing values of variables that satisfy a linear equation into tables for analysis.

name: representation of linear relationships in graphical form
explanation: Plotting points that satisfy a linear equation on a coordinate plane to visualize the relationship.

name: equivalence of slope and rate of change
explanation: Understanding that the slope of a line graph represents the rate at which one variable changes relative to another.

name: interpretation of start value in linear relationships
explanation: Recognizing the y-intercept as the initial value or starting point of a linear relationship in context.

name: point of intersection of two linear relationships
explanation: The coordinate point where two linear graphs meet, representing the solution to their simultaneous equations.

name: strategies for solving problems with two linear relationships
explanation: Using graphical, numerical, or mental methods to find solutions involving up to two linear equations.

name: application of Pythagoras' theorem in right-angled triangles
explanation: Using the relationship a² + b² = c² to find missing sides in right-angled triangles, often in height and distance problems.

name: use of trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles
explanation: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to calculate unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles.

name: identification of axes of symmetry in simple shapes
explanation: Locating lines through a shape where the shape can be folded onto itself perfectly.

name: recognition of images under translation
explanation: Understanding how points or shapes shift uniformly in a plane without rotation or reflection.

name: recognition of images under central symmetry
explanation: Identifying points or shapes reflected through a central point producing an image directly opposite the original.

name: recognition of images under axial symmetry
explanation: Identifying mirror images of points or shapes reflected across a line (axis of symmetry).

name: recognition of images under rotation
explanation: Understanding how points or shapes turn about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

name: investigation of enlargements and their effect on area
explanation: Studying how scaling a shape by a factor k changes its size and area, including cases where 0<k<1 and k>1.

name: centre of enlargement
explanation: The fixed point from which all points of a shape are expanded or contracted during an enlargement.

name: scale factor in enlargements
explanation: The ratio k by which lengths in a shape are multiplied during enlargement, affecting size and area proportionally.

name: use of theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies in deductive reasoning
explanation: Understanding and applying logical terms and structures to formulate and justify geometric arguments.

name: proof by contradiction
explanation: A method of proving a statement by assuming the opposite is true and showing this leads to a contradiction.

name: proof of theorems concerning ratios in geometry
explanation: Demonstrating geometric theorems that involve proportional relationships between segments or figures.

name: use of slope to determine parallelism
explanation: Showing that two lines are parallel if and only if their slopes are equal.

name: use of slope to determine perpendicularity
explanation: Showing that two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1.

name: recognition of linear equation in standard form ax + by + c = 0
explanation: Understanding that equations of the form ax + by + c = 0 represent straight lines in the plane.

name: calculation of area of a triangle using coordinates
explanation: Finding the area of a triangle given the coordinates of its vertices using coordinate geometry formulas.

name: equation of a circle with centre (h, k) and radius r
explanation: The formula (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r² that represents all points at distance r from centre (h, k).

name: equation of a circle with centre (-g, -f) in general form
explanation: The equation x² + y² + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 representing a circle with centre (-g, -f) and radius r = √(g² + f² - c).

name: perpendicular distance from a point to a line
explanation: Calculating the shortest distance between a given point and a line in the coordinate plane.

name: angle between two lines
explanation: Determining the measure of the angle formed where two lines intersect using their slopes.

name: internal division of a line segment in ratio m:n
explanation: Finding the coordinates of a point that divides a line segment internally into parts with lengths proportional to m and n.

name: use of Pythagoras' theorem in 2D problem solving
explanation: Applying the Pythagorean theorem specifically to two-dimensional geometric problems.

name: calculation of area of a triangle using trigonometry
explanation: Using formulas involving sine of an angle to find the area of a triangle when two sides and the included angle are known.

name: application of sine rule in triangle problem solving
explanation: Using the sine rule a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle.

name: application of cosine rule in triangle problem solving
explanation: Using the cosine rule a² = b² + c² - 2bc cos A to find unknown sides or angles in any triangle.

name: definition of sine function for all angle values
explanation: Extending the sine function to be defined for all real values of θ, including beyond acute angles.

name: definition of cosine function for all angle values
explanation: Extending the cosine function to be defined for all real values of θ, including beyond acute angles.

name: definition of tangent function
explanation: Defining the tangent function as the ratio of sine to cosine for an angle θ.

name: calculation of area of a sector of a circle
explanation: Finding the area of a sector using the formula involving radius and central angle in radians or degrees.

name: calculation of length of an arc
explanation: Determining the length of a curved segment of a circle using radius and central angle.

name: working with trigonometric ratios in surd form
explanation: Expressing sine, cosine, and tangent values using irrational numbers in simplest radical form.

name: application of trigonometry in 3D problem solving
explanation: Using trigonometric methods to solve problems involving three-dimensional figures and distances.

name: graphing sine function
explanation: Plotting the sine function values over a range of angles to visualize its periodic behavior.

name: graphing cosine function
explanation: Plotting the cosine function values over a range of angles to visualize its periodic behavior.

name: graphing tangent function
explanation: Plotting the tangent function values over a range of angles, noting asymptotes and periodicity.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of the form f(θ) = a + b sin cθ
explanation: Plotting sine functions with amplitude, vertical shift, and frequency modifications represented by parameters a, b, and c.

name: graphing trigonometric functions of the form g(θ) = a + b cos cθ
explanation: Plotting cosine functions with amplitude, vertical shift, and frequency modifications represented by parameters a, b, and c.

name: solving trigonometric equations sin nθ = 0
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ for which the sine of nθ equals zero, including general solutions.

name: solving trigonometric equations cos nθ = 1/2
explanation: Finding all angle solutions θ for which the cosine of nθ equals one half, including general solutions.

name: use of radian measure of angles
explanation: Measuring angles based on the radius of a circle, where one radian is the angle subtended by an arc equal in length to the radius.

name: derivation of fundamental trigonometric formulae
explanation: Establishing key trigonometric identities and formulas through algebraic and geometric reasoning.

name: application of trigonometric formulae 1-24
explanation: Using a comprehensive set of trigonometric identities and formulas to solve various problems.

name: natural numbers (N)
explanation: The set of positive integers starting from 1, used for counting and ordering.

name: integers (Z)
explanation: The set of whole numbers including positive numbers, zero, and negative numbers.

name: rational numbers (Q)
explanation: Numbers that can be expressed as the quotient of two integers, including fractions and decimals with finite or repeating decimal representations.

name: representing rational numbers as fractions, decimals, and percentages
explanation: Understanding that fractions, decimals (finite or repeating), and percentages are different forms of representing rational numbers.

name: addition of natural numbers using decomposition and skip counting
explanation: Performing addition in natural numbers by breaking numbers into parts or counting in increments.

name: subtraction of natural numbers using inverse operations
explanation: Performing subtraction as the inverse of addition within natural numbers.

name: multiplication of natural numbers using arrays and repeated addition
explanation: Understanding multiplication as repeated addition or arranging items in rows and columns (arrays).

name: division of natural numbers as inverse of multiplication
explanation: Understanding division as the inverse operation of multiplication within natural numbers.

name: properties of arithmetic operations: commutative law
explanation: The property that changing the order of numbers in addition or multiplication does not change the result.

name: properties of arithmetic operations: associative law
explanation: The property that changing the grouping of numbers in addition or multiplication does not change the result.

name: properties of arithmetic operations: distributive law
explanation: The property that multiplication distributes over addition or subtraction, e.g., a(b + c) = ab + ac.

name: order of operations including brackets
explanation: Rules that define the sequence in which operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, powers) are performed, including the use of brackets to alter order.

name: addition with negative integers
explanation: Performing addition where one or both numbers are negative, interpreting in contexts such as temperatures below zero or debts.

name: subtraction with negative integers
explanation: Performing subtraction involving negative numbers, understanding the effect on the number line and real-world contexts.

name: multiplication with negative integers
explanation: Multiplying integers where one or both factors are negative, including rules for signs of the product.

name: division with negative integers
explanation: Dividing integers where one or both numbers are negative, including understanding the sign of the quotient.

name: representing integers on the number line
explanation: Using a number line to visually represent integers and their order, including positive and negative values.

name: representing rational numbers on the number line
explanation: Placing fractions and decimals on the number line to show their relative size and order.

name: irrational numbers
explanation: Numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers, having non-terminating, non-repeating decimal expansions.

name: real numbers (R)
explanation: The set of all rational and irrational numbers combined, representing all points on the number line.

name: complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Numbers expressed as a + ib, where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit with i² = -1.

name: Argand diagram representation of complex numbers
explanation: A graphical representation of complex numbers as points or vectors in the plane, with the horizontal axis representing the real part and the vertical axis the imaginary part.

name: modulus of a complex number
explanation: The distance of a complex number from the origin in the Argand diagram, calculated as the square root of the sum of squares of its real and imaginary parts.

name: complex conjugate
explanation: The complex number obtained by changing the sign of the imaginary part of a complex number a + ib to a - ib.

name: prime numbers in natural numbers
explanation: Natural numbers greater than 1 that have no positive divisors other than 1 and themselves.

name: expressing numbers as products of prime factors
explanation: Representing a number as a multiplication of prime numbers raised to powers, known as prime factorization.

name: scientific notation for positive rational numbers
explanation: Expressing numbers in the form a × 10^n where 1 ≤ a < 10 and n is an integer, to simplify representation of very large or small numbers.

name: geometric construction of square roots (√2 and √3)
explanation: Using geometric methods to construct lengths equal to the square roots of 2 and 3.

name: proof of irrationality of √2
explanation: A mathematical proof demonstrating that the square root of 2 cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers.

name: calculation of conjugates of sums and products of complex numbers
explanation: Finding the conjugate of sums and products of complex numbers using algebraic properties.

name: verification and justification of formulae from number patterns
explanation: Using algebraic and arithmetic reasoning to prove formulas derived from observed numerical patterns.

name: investigation of geometric sequences and series
explanation: Studying sequences where each term is found by multiplying the previous term by a constant ratio, and their sums.

name: proof by mathematical induction of simple identities
explanation: Using the principle of induction to prove formulas such as the sum of the first n natural numbers or finite geometric series.

name: proof by mathematical induction of inequalities
explanation: Using induction to prove inequalities involving natural numbers, such as factorial and exponential inequalities.

name: proof by mathematical induction of factorisation results
explanation: Using induction to prove divisibility or factorization properties of algebraic expressions.

name: limits of sequences
explanation: Determining the value that a sequence approaches as the index goes to infinity.

name: sum to infinity of geometric series
explanation: Calculating the sum of an infinite geometric series when the common ratio's absolute value is less than one.

name: equality as a relationship between expressions
explanation: Understanding that equality means two expressions represent the same value or quantity.

name: calculating percentages
explanation: Finding a portion of a quantity expressed as a fraction of 100.

name: equivalence of fractions, decimals, and percentages
explanation: Converting and comparing numbers expressed as fractions, decimals, and percentages to understand proportional relationships.

name: relationship between ratio and proportion
explanation: Understanding how ratios compare quantities and how proportions express equality of two ratios.

name: checking results by order of magnitude and inverse operations
explanation: Verifying answers by estimating size and working backwards through calculations.

name: making and justifying estimates and approximations
explanation: Using rounding and approximation strategies to simplify calculations and justify their reasonableness.

name: presenting numerical answers to specified degrees of accuracy
explanation: Rounding or truncating answers to a required number of decimal places or significant figures.

name: indices as squares, cubes, square roots, and reciprocals
explanation: Representing numbers using powers such as squares (power 2), cubes (power 3), square roots (power 1/2), and reciprocals (power -1).

name: rules of indices: product rule
explanation: The rule that multiplying powers with the same base adds their exponents: a^p × a^q = a^(p+q).

name: rules of indices: quotient rule
explanation: The rule that dividing powers with the same base subtracts the exponents: a^p ÷ a^q = a^(p−q).

name: rules of indices: zero exponent rule
explanation: Any non-zero base raised to the zero power equals one: a^0 = 1.

name: rules of indices: power of a power rule
explanation: Raising a power to another power multiplies the exponents: (a^p)^q = a^(pq).

name: rules of indices: negative exponent rule
explanation: A negative exponent represents the reciprocal of the positive exponent: a^(-p) = 1/a^p.

name: rules of indices: power of a product and quotient
explanation: Raising a product or quotient to a power applies the exponent to each factor: (ab)^p = a^p b^p and (a/b)^p = a^p / b^p.

name: logarithm rules: product rule
explanation: The logarithm of a product equals the sum of the logarithms: log_a(xy) = log_a x + log_a y.

name: logarithm rules: quotient rule
explanation: The logarithm of a quotient equals the difference of the logarithms: log_a(x/y) = log_a x − log_a y.

name: logarithm rules: power rule
explanation: The logarithm of a power equals the exponent times the logarithm: log_a(x^q) = q log_a x.

name: logarithm of base and one
explanation: Logarithm of the base equals one and logarithm of one equals zero: log_a a = 1 and log_a 1 = 0.

name: change of base formula for logarithms
explanation: Expressing logarithms in terms of logs with a different base: log_a x = log_b x / log_b a.

name: solving everyday arithmetic problems involving profit and loss
explanation: Calculating profit, loss, percentages of profit or loss based on cost price, and related financial quantities.

name: calculating discount and percentage discount
explanation: Determining the amount and percentage reduction from an original price.

name: calculating selling price after discount or markup
explanation: Finding the final price after applying discount or markup percentages to the cost price.

name: compound interest calculation for up to 3 years
explanation: Calculating interest on principal and accumulated interest over multiple years using compound interest formula.

name: income tax calculation at standard rate
explanation: Computing tax payable on income using a fixed tax rate.

name: net pay calculation including deductions
explanation: Determining take-home pay after subtracting specified deductions such as taxes and other amounts.

name: calculating average speed, distance, and time
explanation: Solving problems using the relationship speed = distance/time to find any one quantity given the other two.

name: understanding and using nets of 3D solids
explanation: Representing three-dimensional solids as two-dimensional nets to analyze surface area and volume.

name: distinguishing between surface area and volume
explanation: Understanding that surface area measures the total area covering a solid's surface, while volume measures the space inside the solid.

name: calculating perimeter of plane figures
explanation: Finding the total length around 2D shapes such as discs, triangles, rectangles, and squares.

name: calculating area of regular and irregular plane figures
explanation: Determining the surface enclosed by 2D shapes including combinations of basic shapes and irregular figures.

name: calculating surface area of rectangular solids and cylinders
explanation: Finding the total area covering the surfaces of rectangular prisms and cylinders.

name: calculating volume of rectangular solids and cylinders
explanation: Determining the amount of space inside rectangular prisms and cylinders.

name: calculating surface area and volume of spheres and hemispheres
explanation: Finding the total surface area and volume of spheres and half-spheres (hemispheres).

name: calculating surface area and volume of cones and prisms
explanation: Determining surface area and volume for right cones and triangular-based prisms including isosceles and equilateral types.

name: using the trapezoidal rule to approximate area
explanation: Estimating the area under a curve by dividing it into trapezoids and summing their areas.

name: checking results by order of magnitude and working backwards
explanation: Verifying answers by estimating their size and reversing the calculation steps to confirm correctness.

name: accumulated error by addition or subtraction
explanation: Understanding how errors add up when quantities are combined by addition or subtraction.

name: calculating percentage error and tolerance
explanation: Measuring the accuracy of a value by comparing the difference from the true value as a percentage and defining acceptable error margins.

name: calculating average rates of change with respect to time
explanation: Determining how a quantity changes on average over a time interval.

name: calculating cost price, selling price, loss, discount, mark up, and margin
explanation: Solving problems involving buying and selling prices, profit or loss percentages, and related financial calculations.

name: calculating compound interest and depreciation using reducing balance method
explanation: Computing interest compounded over time and asset value decrease using a percentage of the current value.

name: costing including materials, labour, and wastage
explanation: Calculating total costs by adding expenses for materials, labor, and waste in production or projects.

name: metric and imperial unit conversions
explanation: Converting measurements between metric units and everyday imperial units using conversion factors.

name: making estimates of physical world measures
explanation: Using approximation skills to estimate measurements encountered in real-life contexts.

name: using present value in loan repayments and investments
explanation: Calculating the current worth of future sums of money to solve financial problems involving loans and investments.

name: function as unique output assignment
explanation: Understanding that a function assigns exactly one output value for each input value.

name: graphing linear functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax + b where a and b are rational numbers and x is a real number.

name: forming composite functions
explanation: Creating new functions by applying one function to the result of another function, denoted as (f ∘ g)(x) = f(g(x)).

name: graphing quadratic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax² + bx + c where a, b, and c are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing cubic functions with integer coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = ax³ + bx² + cx + d where a, b, c, and d are integers and x is a real number.

name: graphing power functions with natural base and real exponents
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = a b^x where a is a natural number and b, x are real numbers.

name: interpreting equations f(x) = g(x) as function comparisons
explanation: Understanding equations where two functions are equal and analyzing their graphs or algebraic forms to find solutions or intersections.

name: graphical methods for approximate solutions to f(x) = 0
explanation: Using graphs to estimate the roots or zeros of a function where the function value equals zero.

name: graphical methods for approximate solutions to f(x) = k
explanation: Using graphs to estimate points where the function equals a constant k.

name: graphical methods for approximate solutions to f(x) = g(x)
explanation: Using graphs to find approximate solutions where two functions have equal values.

name: investigating the concept of function limits
explanation: Exploring the behavior of functions as inputs approach a particular value, including approaching infinity or finite points.

name: recognising surjective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where every element in the codomain has at least one pre-image in the domain.

name: recognising injective functions
explanation: Identifying functions where each element of the domain maps to a unique element in the codomain, with no duplicates.

name: recognising bijective functions
explanation: Identifying functions that are both injective and surjective, establishing a one-to-one correspondence between domain and codomain.

name: finding inverse of bijective functions
explanation: Determining the function that reverses the effect of a bijection, swapping inputs and outputs.

name: sketching inverse function graphs from given function graphs
explanation: Drawing the graph of an inverse function by reflecting the original function's graph across the line y = x.

name: expressing quadratic functions in complete square form
explanation: Rewriting quadratic functions as f(x) = a(x - h)² + k to identify vertex form and analyze properties easily.

name: using complete square form to find roots and turning points
explanation: Applying the vertex form of a quadratic to determine the function's zeros and maximum or minimum points.

name: graphing quadratic functions with rational coefficients
explanation: Plotting quadratic functions where coefficients a, b, and c are rational numbers and x is real.

name: graphing exponential functions with real coefficients
explanation: Plotting functions of the form f(x) = a^x where a and x are real numbers, including growth and decay behaviors.

name: graphing logarithmic functions
explanation: Plotting functions that are the inverses of exponential functions, typically of the form f(x) = log_a(x).

name: graphing trigonometric functions
explanation: Plotting periodic functions such as sine, cosine, and tangent over real numbers.

name: informal exploration of limits and continuity
explanation: Investigating how functions behave near points of interest and whether they are continuous without formal epsilon-delta definitions.

name: finding first derivatives of linear functions by rule
explanation: Calculating the derivative of linear functions using differentiation rules to find constant slopes.

name: finding first derivatives of quadratic functions by rule
explanation: Applying differentiation rules to quadratic functions to find their rate of change functions.

name: finding first derivatives of cubic functions by rule
explanation: Using differentiation rules to compute derivatives of cubic polynomial functions.

name: finding second derivatives of linear, quadratic, and cubic functions
explanation: Calculating the derivative of the first derivative to analyze concavity and acceleration of functions.

name: associating derivatives with slopes and tangent lines
explanation: Understanding that the derivative at a point represents the slope of the tangent line to the function's graph at that point.

name: applying differentiation to rates of change
explanation: Using derivatives to calculate how quantities change with respect to one another in various contexts.

name: applying differentiation to find maxima and minima
explanation: Using derivatives to identify local maximum and minimum points of functions by analyzing critical points.

name: applying differentiation to curve sketching
explanation: Using first and second derivatives to determine the shape, turning points, and concavity of graphs.

name: differentiating linear and quadratic functions from first principles
explanation: Calculating derivatives using the limit definition rather than rules for linear and quadratic functions.

name: differentiating polynomial functions
explanation: Applying differentiation rules to find derivatives of polynomial functions of any degree.

name: differentiating exponential functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions involving exponential expressions, including base e and other bases.

name: differentiating trigonometric functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of sine, cosine, and other trigonometric functions.

name: differentiating functions with rational powers
explanation: Applying differentiation rules to functions where variables are raised to fractional exponents.

name: differentiating inverse functions
explanation: Finding derivatives of functions defined as inverses of other functions using implicit differentiation or formulas.

name: differentiating logarithmic functions
explanation: Calculating derivatives of logarithmic functions such as natural logarithm and logarithms with other bases.

name: differentiating sums and differences of functions
explanation: Applying linearity of differentiation to find derivatives of sums or differences of functions.

name: differentiating products of functions
explanation: Using the product rule to find the derivative of the product of two functions.

name: differentiating quotients of functions
explanation: Applying the quotient rule to differentiate the ratio of two functions.

name: differentiating compositions of functions
explanation: Using the chain rule to find derivatives of composite functions where one function is applied inside another.

name: using differentiation to find slope of tangent to a circle
explanation: Applying derivatives to determine the slope of the tangent line at a point on a circle's curve.

name: recognising integration as reverse of differentiation
explanation: Understanding that integration reverses the process of differentiation, recovering original functions from derivatives.

name: using integration to find average value of a function over interval
explanation: Calculating the mean value of a function on an interval by integrating and dividing by the interval length.

name: integrating sums, differences, and constant multiples of functions
explanation: Applying linearity of integration to integrate combinations of functions multiplied by constants.

name: integrating power functions with rational exponents
explanation: Finding integrals of functions of the form x^a where a is a rational number.

name: integrating exponential functions with positive real base
explanation: Calculating integrals of functions of the form a^x where a > 0 and a is real.

name: integrating sine functions with real coefficients
explanation: Finding integrals of functions of the form sin(ax) where a is a real number.

name: integrating cosine functions with real coefficients
explanation: Calculating integrals of functions of the form cos(ax) where a is a real number.

name: determining areas bounded by polynomial curves
explanation: Using integration to find the area of plane regions enclosed by polynomial function graphs and the x-axis or other curves.

name: determining areas bounded by exponential curves
explanation: Applying integration to calculate areas of regions enclosed by exponential function graphs and other boundaries.

name: sketching the function
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: sketching the function

name: finding first and second derivatives of linear, quadratic and cubic functions by rule
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: finding first and second derivatives of linear, quadratic and cubic functions by rule

name: Representing repeating patterns with tables
explanation: Using tables to organize inputs and outputs to represent and analyze repeating numerical or visual patterns.

name: Generalising numeric and verbal patterns
explanation: Formulating general rules or descriptions that explain how patterns progress, expressed in words or numbers.

name: Writing arithmetic expressions for sequence terms
explanation: Constructing arithmetic expressions that represent specific terms in a sequence based on pattern rules.

name: Representing linear patterns with tables, diagrams, and graphs
explanation: Using various visual tools such as tables, diagrams, and graphs to depict and analyze linear relationships and patterns.

name: Developing and using generalising strategies for patterns
explanation: Creating and applying methods to identify and explain patterns and relationships, including considering others' strategies.

name: Presenting and interpreting solutions with justification
explanation: Communicating problem solutions clearly, explaining reasoning and justifying methods used.

name: Finding formulae for linear relationships from patterns
explanation: Deriving algebraic formulas that express linear relationships identified from patterns or data.

name: Identifying features of linear relationships
explanation: Recognizing key characteristics of linear relationships such as constant rate of change and proportionality across different representations.

name: Representing linear relationships in multiple forms
explanation: Expressing linear relationships using tables, graphs, physical models, and verbal or algebraic formulas.

name: Reasoning using rate of change and y-intercept
explanation: Using the concepts of rate of change (slope) and y-intercept to analyze and interpret linear relationships in context.

name: Determining common values of two linear relationships
explanation: Finding points where two linear relationships intersect or share the same output value.

name: Recognising and solving direct proportion problems
explanation: Identifying problems involving direct proportionality and using given information to find solutions.

name: Interpreting quantitative graphs of phenomena
explanation: Analyzing graphs that represent real-world quantities and drawing conclusions about the phenomena they describe.

name: Describing quantity and change on graphs
explanation: Explaining both the amount and the rate or nature of change represented in a graph.

name: Evaluating algebraic expressions with given variable values
explanation: Calculating the numerical value of algebraic expressions by substituting specific values for variables.

name: Expanding and regrouping algebraic expressions
explanation: Applying distributive properties to multiply out expressions and rearranging terms to simplify or organize them.

name: Factorising quadratic expressions
explanation: Breaking down second-degree polynomial expressions into products of simpler binomial expressions.

name: Adding and subtracting linear and quadratic expressions
explanation: Performing addition and subtraction operations on polynomial expressions of degree one and two, combining like terms.

name: Simplifying expressions using associative and distributive properties
explanation: Applying associative and distributive laws to simplify complex algebraic expressions involving multiple terms and brackets.

name: Multiplying binomials
explanation: Using distributive property to multiply two binomial expressions resulting in a polynomial.

name: Rearranging formulae
explanation: Manipulating algebraic formulas to isolate a specific variable or express the formula in an equivalent form.

name: Arithmetic operations on polynomials and rational expressions
explanation: Performing addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division on polynomial and rational algebraic expressions, including careful use of brackets and surds.

name: Applying the binomial theorem
explanation: Using the binomial theorem to expand powers of binomial expressions systematically.

name: Solving linear equations of the form f(x) = g(x)
explanation: Finding values of x that satisfy equations where both sides are linear expressions, using graphic, numeric, or mental strategies.

name: Solving linear inequalities of the form g(x) ≤ k or g(x) ≥ k
explanation: Determining solution sets for inequalities where a linear expression is compared to a constant, using various strategies and interpreting results.

name: Solving linear inequalities of the form g(x) < k or g(x) > k
explanation: Finding solution sets for strict linear inequalities using graphic, numeric, algebraic, or mental methods.

name: Solving linear equations with rational coefficients
explanation: Solving linear equations where coefficients and constants are rational numbers, using appropriate strategies.

name: Solving quadratic equations with rational coefficients
explanation: Finding solutions to quadratic equations with rational coefficients, including cases where the quadratic is not factorable, using various methods.

name: Solving simultaneous linear equations with two unknowns
explanation: Finding values of two variables that satisfy two linear equations simultaneously using graphic, numeric, algebraic, or mental strategies.

name: Solving systems with one linear and one quadratic equation
explanation: Finding solutions to systems consisting of one linear and one quadratic equation with two unknowns, with restrictions on coefficients.

name: Forming quadratic equations from given roots
explanation: Constructing quadratic equations when the roots (solutions) are known whole numbers.

name: Using the Factor Theorem for polynomials
explanation: Applying the Factor Theorem to determine if a linear binomial is a factor of a polynomial and to find polynomial roots.

name: Solving cubic equations with at least one integer root
explanation: Finding solutions to cubic polynomial equations where at least one root is an integer, using suitable strategies.

name: Solving simultaneous linear equations with three unknowns
explanation: Finding solutions to systems of three linear equations involving three variables using appropriate methods.

name: Using absolute value notation in inequalities
explanation: Applying and interpreting absolute value expressions and inequalities involving absolute values in solution strategies.

name: Solving quadratic inequalities
explanation: Finding solution sets for inequalities where the expression is quadratic, using graphic, numeric, algebraic, or mental methods.

name: Solving compound inequalities involving absolute values
explanation: Determining solution sets for inequalities combining absolute value expressions with relational operators and constants.

name: Using the Conjugate Root Theorem
explanation: Applying the theorem that complex roots of polynomials with real coefficients occur in conjugate pairs to find polynomial roots.

name: Working with complex numbers in rectangular form
explanation: Representing and manipulating complex numbers expressed as a + bi, where a and b are real numbers.

name: Working with complex numbers in polar form
explanation: Expressing complex numbers using magnitude and angle (r(cos θ + i sin θ)) and performing operations in this form.

name: Using De Moivre’s Theorem
explanation: Applying De Moivre’s Theorem to raise complex numbers in polar form to integer powers and find roots.

name: Proving De Moivre’s Theorem by induction
explanation: Demonstrating the validity of De Moivre’s Theorem for natural numbers using mathematical induction.

name: Finding nth roots of unity
explanation: Calculating the complex solutions to the equation z^n = 1, which are equally spaced on the unit circle in the complex plane.

name: Using trigonometric identities involving cosine of multiple angles
explanation: Applying identities such as Cos 3θ = 4 Cos³ θ – 3 Cos θ to simplify or solve trigonometric expressions.

name: Relations without formulae
explanation: Concept referenced in relationship: Relations without formulae

name: line passing through a given point
explanation: A line that contains a specific point in the plane, defined as the set of points including that point and extending infinitely in both directions.

name: undefined geometric terms
explanation: Basic geometric terms such as angle, degree, length, line, plane, point, ray, real number, and set, which are accepted without formal definition as foundational concepts.

name: defined geometric terms
explanation: Geometric terms that are explicitly defined, including area, parallel lines, parallelogram, right angle, triangle, congruent triangles, similar triangles, tangent to a circle, and others.

name: collinear points
explanation: Three or more points that lie on the same straight line.

name: line segment
explanation: The part of a line between two points, including the endpoints.

name: ray (half-line)
explanation: A part of a line that starts at a point and extends infinitely in one direction.

name: distance between two points
explanation: The non-negative length of the line segment connecting two points, denoted |AB|.

name: midpoint of a segment
explanation: The point on a segment that divides it into two equal parts.

name: convex set
explanation: A subset of the plane where, for any two points in the set, the entire segment connecting them lies within the set.

name: angle vertex and arms
explanation: An angle consists of a vertex point and two rays (arms) starting at the vertex, defining the angle's opening.

name: null angle
explanation: An angle whose two arms coincide and whose interior is empty, measuring 0 degrees.

name: ordinary angle
explanation: An angle with arms not on the same line and whose interior is a convex set, measuring between 0 and 180 degrees.

name: straight angle
explanation: An angle whose arms are opposite rays forming a straight line, measuring exactly 180 degrees.

name: reflex angle
explanation: An angle with arms not on the same line and whose interior is not convex, measuring between 180 and 360 degrees.

name: full angle
explanation: An angle whose arms coincide and whose interior is the entire plane except the arms, measuring 360 degrees.

name: angle notation with three points
explanation: Notation \BAC or \CAB denotes the angle with vertex A and arms passing through points B and C.

name: degree measure of an angle
explanation: The numerical measure of an angle in degrees, ranging from 0° to 360°, denoted |\BAC| or |\alpha|.

name: protractor axiom
explanation: The axiom stating that angles have degree measures between 0° and 360°, with properties including existence and uniqueness of rays forming given angles.

name: angle bisector
explanation: A ray starting at the vertex of an angle that divides the angle into two equal angles.

name: right angle
explanation: An angle measuring exactly 90 degrees.

name: acute angle
explanation: An angle measuring less than 90 degrees.

name: obtuse angle
explanation: An angle measuring more than 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees.

name: supplementary angles
explanation: Two angles whose measures add up to 180 degrees.

name: perpendicular lines
explanation: Two lines intersecting to form a right angle (90 degrees).

name: vertically opposite angles
explanation: Pairs of angles opposite each other when two lines intersect, which are equal in measure.

name: triangle definition
explanation: A polygon formed by three non-collinear points connected by three line segments called sides, with vertices at the points.

name: triangle side length notation
explanation: Sides of a triangle are denoted by lowercase letters a, b, c, opposite vertices A, B, C respectively.

name: triangle congruence criteria (SAS, ASA, SSS)
explanation: Conditions under which two triangles are congruent: Side-Angle-Side (SAS), Angle-Side-Angle (ASA), and Side-Side-Side (SSS).

name: right-angled triangle
explanation: A triangle with one angle measuring exactly 90 degrees; the side opposite this angle is called the hypotenuse.

name: isosceles triangle
explanation: A triangle with at least two sides equal in length, and consequently two equal angles opposite those sides.

name: equilateral triangle
explanation: A triangle with all three sides equal in length and all three angles equal.

name: scalene triangle
explanation: A triangle with no two sides equal in length.

name: parallel lines
explanation: Two lines in a plane that are either identical or have no points in common and never intersect.

name: transversal line
explanation: A line that intersects two or more other lines at distinct points.

name: alternate angles
explanation: Pairs of angles on opposite sides of a transversal but inside the two lines it intersects, equal if the lines are parallel.

name: corresponding angles
explanation: Pairs of angles in matching corners when a transversal crosses two lines; equal if the lines are parallel.

name: angle sum of triangle
explanation: The sum of the interior angles of any triangle is always 180 degrees.

name: exterior angle of a triangle
explanation: An angle formed outside a triangle when one side is extended; equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles.

name: triangle inequality
explanation: The sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle is greater than the length of the third side.

name: perpendicular bisector of a segment
explanation: A line that passes through the midpoint of a segment and is perpendicular to it.

name: polygon definition
explanation: A closed chain of line segments laid end-to-end, not crossing and not making straight angles at endpoints, enclosing a region of the plane.

name: quadrilateral
explanation: A polygon with exactly four vertices and four sides.

name: opposite sides and angles of quadrilateral
explanation: Pairs of sides or angles in a quadrilateral that are not adjacent to each other.

name: rectangle
explanation: A quadrilateral with all four interior angles equal to 90 degrees.

name: rhombus
explanation: A quadrilateral with all four sides equal in length.

name: square
explanation: A quadrilateral that is both a rectangle and a rhombus, having equal sides and all right angles.

name: parallelogram
explanation: A quadrilateral where both pairs of opposite sides are parallel.

name: diagonals of parallelogram bisect each other
explanation: The diagonals of a parallelogram intersect at their midpoints, dividing each other into equal parts.

name: similar triangles
explanation: Triangles with corresponding angles equal and corresponding sides in proportion.

name: ratio division of a segment
explanation: A point divides a segment into two parts whose lengths are in a given ratio s:t.

name: parallel line cutting sides of triangle in same ratio
explanation: A line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides proportionally.

name: Pythagorean theorem
explanation: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

name: converse of Pythagorean theorem
explanation: If the square of one side of a triangle equals the sum of the squares of the other two sides, then the triangle has a right angle opposite that side.

name: RHS congruence criterion
explanation: Two right-angled triangles are congruent if their hypotenuses and one other side are equal in length.

name: altitude of a triangle
explanation: A perpendicular segment from a vertex to the line containing the opposite side, representing the height relative to that base.

name: area of a triangle
explanation: Half the product of a chosen base length and its corresponding height (altitude).

name: area addition property for triangles
explanation: The area of a triangle split by a segment into two smaller triangles equals the sum of the areas of the two smaller triangles.

name: area of rectangle
explanation: The product of the lengths of its two adjacent sides.

name: area of parallelogram
explanation: The product of the base length and the corresponding height (altitude).

name: circle definition
explanation: The set of all points in a plane at a fixed distance (radius) from a fixed point (centre).

name: radius of a circle
explanation: A line segment from the centre of a circle to any point on the circle.

name: diameter of a circle
explanation: A chord passing through the centre of the circle; its length is twice the radius.

name: chord of a circle
explanation: A line segment with both endpoints on the circle.

name: arc of a circle
explanation: A continuous portion of the circumference of a circle between two points.

name: sector of a circle
explanation: The region enclosed by two radii and the arc between their endpoints.

name: circumference of a circle
explanation: The total length of the circle's boundary.

name: pi (π) constant
explanation: The ratio of the circumference of any circle to its diameter, approximately 3.14159.

name: semicircle
explanation: An arc of a circle whose endpoints are the endpoints of a diameter.

name: disc
explanation: The region inside a circle, including the boundary.

name: angle standing on an arc
explanation: An angle formed at a point outside the arc, with its arms passing through the endpoints of the arc.

name: angle at centre standing on arc
explanation: The angle formed at the centre of a circle by two radii to the endpoints of an arc; it is twice the angle at any point on the circle standing on the same arc.

name: angles standing on same arc are equal
explanation: All angles at points on the circle standing on the same arc are equal in measure.

name: angle in a semicircle is right angle
explanation: An angle standing on a diameter of a circle is a right angle (90 degrees).

name: cyclic quadrilateral
explanation: A quadrilateral whose vertices all lie on the circumference of a circle.

name: opposite angles of cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180 degrees
explanation: In a cyclic quadrilateral, each pair of opposite angles add up to 180 degrees.

name: tangent to a circle
explanation: A line that touches the circle at exactly one point, called the point of contact.

name: tangent perpendicular to radius
explanation: A tangent line to a circle is perpendicular to the radius drawn to the point of contact.

name: point on perpendicular bisector equidistant from segment endpoints
explanation: Any point on the perpendicular bisector of a segment is equidistant from the segment's endpoints.

name: perpendicular bisector passes through circle centre
explanation: The perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the centre of the circle.

name: circumcircle of a triangle
explanation: The unique circle passing through all three vertices of a triangle.

name: circumcentre of a triangle
explanation: The centre of the circumcircle of a triangle, located at the intersection of the perpendicular bisectors of the sides.

name: incircle of a triangle
explanation: The circle inside a triangle tangent to each of its sides.

name: incentre of a triangle
explanation: The centre of the incircle of a triangle, located at the intersection of the angle bisectors.

name: median of a triangle
explanation: A line segment joining a vertex of a triangle to the midpoint of the opposite side.

name: centroid of a triangle
explanation: The point where the three medians of a triangle intersect.

name: altitudes of a triangle
explanation: Perpendicular segments from each vertex to the opposite side or its extension.

name: orthocentre of a triangle
explanation: The point where the three altitudes of a triangle intersect.

name: geometric construction with compass and straight-edge
explanation: Methods to create geometric figures such as lines, angles, and circles using only a compass and straight-edge.

name: angle bisector construction
explanation: Constructing the ray that divides a given angle into two equal angles using compass and straight-edge.

name: perpendicular bisector construction
explanation: Constructing the line perpendicular to a segment at its midpoint using compass and straight-edge.

name: line perpendicular to given line through external point
explanation: Constructing a line perpendicular to a given line passing through a point not on the line.

name: line perpendicular to given line through point on line
explanation: Constructing a line perpendicular to a given line passing through a point on the line.

name: parallel line construction through given point
explanation: Constructing a line parallel to a given line passing through a specified point.

name: division of segment into equal parts without measurement
explanation: Constructing points dividing a segment into equal segments using geometric methods without measuring lengths.

name: constructing segment of given length on ray
explanation: Marking a point on a ray such that the segment from the vertex to that point has a specified length.

name: constructing angle of given degree measure
explanation: Creating an angle with a specified number of degrees using geometric tools.

name: triangle construction given three sides
explanation: Constructing a triangle when the lengths of all three sides are known.

name: triangle construction given SAS data
explanation: Constructing a triangle given two sides and the included angle.

name: triangle construction given ASA data
explanation: Constructing a triangle given two angles and the included side.

name: right-angled triangle construction given hypotenuse and side
explanation: Constructing a right-angled triangle when the hypotenuse and one other side length are known.

name: right-angled triangle construction given side and acute angle
explanation: Constructing a right-angled triangle given one side length and one acute angle.

name: rectangle construction given side lengths
explanation: Constructing a rectangle when the lengths of two adjacent sides are specified.

name: circumcentre and circumcircle construction
explanation: Constructing the circumcentre and circumcircle of a triangle using compass and straight-edge.

name: incentre and incircle construction
explanation: Constructing the incentre and incircle of a triangle using compass and straight-edge.

name: constructing 60 degree angle without protractor
explanation: Constructing a 60° angle using only compass and straight-edge, without measuring tools.

name: tangent to circle at given point construction
explanation: Constructing the tangent line to a circle at a specified point on the circle.

name: parallelogram construction given sides and angles
explanation: Constructing a parallelogram when the lengths of the sides and measures of the angles are given.

name: centroid construction of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the centroid by drawing medians and locating their intersection point.

name: orthocentre construction of a triangle
explanation: Constructing the orthocentre by drawing altitudes and locating their intersection point.

name: Systematic listing of experiment outcomes
explanation: The process of enumerating all possible results of a random experiment in an organized manner.

name: Fundamental principle of counting
explanation: A counting rule stating that if one event can occur in m ways and another independent event can occur in n ways, then the total number of ways both events can occur is m × n.

name: Informal probability estimation
explanation: Using everyday language and intuition to judge how likely an event is to occur without formal calculation.

name: Probability as a measure on scale 0 to 1
explanation: Understanding probability as a numerical value between 0 and 1 representing the likelihood of an event occurring, where 0 means impossible and 1 means certain.

name: Probability language for equally likely outcomes
explanation: Using terms like 'likely', 'unlikely', 'certain', and 'impossible' to describe events with equally probable outcomes.

name: Experimental probability estimation
explanation: Estimating the probability of an event by conducting experiments and calculating the relative frequency of the event's occurrence.

name: Law of large numbers (long-run relative frequency)
explanation: The principle that as the number of repetitions of an experiment increases, the experimental probability tends to approach the theoretical probability.

name: Construction of sample spaces for two independent events
explanation: Creating a complete list of all possible ordered pairs of outcomes when two independent events occur.

name: Probability calculation for equally likely outcomes
explanation: Calculating probability by dividing the number of favorable outcomes by the total number of equally likely outcomes.

name: Counting permutations of n distinct objects (n!)
explanation: Calculating the number of ways to arrange n distinct objects in order, given by n factorial (n!).

name: Counting permutations of r objects from n distinct objects
explanation: Calculating the number of ordered arrangements of r objects selected from n distinct objects.

name: Calculation of binomial coefficients
explanation: Computing the number of ways to choose r objects from n distinct objects without regard to order, often denoted as n choose r.

name: Set theory in probability
explanation: Using sets to represent events, outcomes, and sample spaces, facilitating the understanding of relationships between events.

name: Use of Venn diagrams for probability rules
explanation: Applying Venn diagrams to visualize and understand the relationships between events, including intersections, unions, and mutually exclusive events.

name: Expected value calculation
explanation: Computing the weighted average of all possible outcomes of a random variable, representing the long-term average result.

name: Role of expected value in decision making
explanation: Using expected value to evaluate the fairness or advantage of games and decisions involving chance.

name: Addition rule for probability
explanation: Calculating the probability of the union of two events using P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B).

name: Multiplication rule for independent events
explanation: Calculating the probability of the intersection of two independent events as P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B).

name: General multiplication rule for dependent events
explanation: Calculating the probability of the intersection of two events where one depends on the other using P(A ∩ B) = P(A) × P(B | A).

name: Sampling with replacement probability
explanation: Calculating probabilities when objects are selected from a population and replaced before the next selection, maintaining constant probabilities.

name: Sampling without replacement probability
explanation: Calculating probabilities when objects are selected from a population without replacement, causing probabilities to change after each selection.

name: Conditional probability and its asymmetry
explanation: Understanding that the probability of A given B is generally not equal to the probability of B given A, expressed as P(A | B) ≠ P(B | A).

name: Probability of two independent events both occurring
explanation: Calculating the probability that two independent events happen simultaneously by multiplying their individual probabilities.

name: Bernoulli trials
explanation: A sequence of independent experiments each with two possible outcomes (success or failure) and constant probability of success.

name: Probability of k successes in n Bernoulli trials
explanation: Calculating the probability of obtaining exactly k successes in n independent Bernoulli trials.

name: Probability that the kth success occurs on the nth Bernoulli trial
explanation: Calculating the probability that the kth success in a sequence of Bernoulli trials happens exactly at the nth trial.

name: Use of simulations to explore sampling variability
explanation: Using computational methods to model repeated sampling from a population to understand variability in sample statistics.

name: Construction of sampling distributions of the mean
explanation: Creating the probability distribution of sample means obtained from repeated samples of a population.

name: Reading probabilities from normal distribution tables
explanation: Using standard normal tables to find probabilities and percentiles associated with normally distributed variables.

name: Distinction between categorical nominal and ordinal data
explanation: Understanding that nominal data represent categories without order, while ordinal data represent categories with a meaningful order.

name: Distinction between numerical discrete and continuous data
explanation: Recognizing that discrete data take countable values, while continuous data can take any value within an interval.

name: Population and sample concepts
explanation: Understanding the difference between the entire group being studied (population) and a subset selected for analysis (sample).

name: Generalizability of conclusions from samples
explanation: Assessing the extent to which results from a sample can be applied to the whole population.

name: Simple random sampling
explanation: Selecting a sample from a population such that every member has an equal chance of being chosen.

name: Stratified sampling
explanation: Sampling method where the population is divided into subgroups (strata) and samples are taken from each stratum proportionally.

name: Cluster sampling
explanation: Sampling method where the population is divided into clusters and entire clusters are randomly selected for the sample.

name: Quota sampling
explanation: Non-random sampling method where samples are selected to meet predefined quotas representing population characteristics.

name: Bias in sampling
explanation: Systematic error introduced when a sample is not representative of the population, affecting the validity of conclusions.

name: Designing data collection plans
explanation: Planning how to gather data effectively, considering sampling methods, representativeness, and potential biases.

name: Use of pie charts for univariate data
explanation: Representing categorical data as slices of a circle, showing proportions of each category.

name: Use of bar charts for univariate data
explanation: Displaying categorical or discrete numerical data with rectangular bars representing frequencies or proportions.

name: Use of line plots for univariate data
explanation: Representing numerical data on a number line with marks or dots indicating frequencies of values.

name: Use of histograms with equal intervals
explanation: Displaying continuous numerical data by grouping values into equal-width bins and representing frequencies with bars.

name: Use of stem-and-leaf plots
explanation: Organizing numerical data to show distribution while retaining original data values by splitting numbers into stems and leaves.

name: Comparing data sets using graphical displays
explanation: Using visual methods such as side-by-side bar charts or back-to-back stem-and-leaf plots to compare two or more data sets.

name: Measures of central tendency: mean
explanation: Calculating the arithmetic average of a data set by summing all values and dividing by the number of values.

name: Measures of central tendency: median
explanation: Identifying the middle value in an ordered data set, dividing the data into two equal halves.

name: Measures of central tendency: mode
explanation: The value(s) that occur most frequently in a data set.

name: Range as a measure of variability
explanation: The difference between the maximum and minimum values in a data set, indicating spread.

name: Symmetry and skewness of data distributions
explanation: Describing the shape of a data distribution as symmetric (balanced) or skewed (asymmetric, with a tail on one side).

name: Scatterplots for bivariate data
explanation: Graphical representation of paired data points on a coordinate plane to examine relationships between two variables.

name: Correlation coefficient interpretation
explanation: Understanding the numerical measure ranging from -1 to +1 that quantifies the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.

name: Correlation does not imply causality
explanation: Recognizing that a statistical association between variables does not necessarily mean one causes the other.

name: Standard deviation as a measure of variability
explanation: A statistic that quantifies the average distance of data points from the mean, indicating spread.

name: Interquartile range (IQR) calculation and use
explanation: The difference between the third and first quartiles, measuring the spread of the middle 50% of data.

name: Quartiles and percentiles for data analysis
explanation: Dividing data into equal parts to understand distribution and relative standing of values within the data set.

name: Identification and effect of outliers
explanation: Detecting data points that lie far outside the typical range and understanding their impact on statistical measures.

name: Drawing line of best fit by eye
explanation: Estimating a straight line that best represents the trend in a scatterplot to summarize the relationship between two variables.

name: Making predictions from line of best fit
explanation: Using the line of best fit to estimate values of one variable based on known values of the other variable.

name: Calculation of correlation coefficient using calculator
explanation: Using technology to compute the precise numerical value of the correlation coefficient for paired data.

name: Interpretation of graphical data summaries
explanation: Analyzing charts and plots to extract meaningful information and relate it to the context or question.

name: Sampling variability and its influence on inference
explanation: Understanding that different samples from the same population can produce different results, affecting conclusions drawn.

name: Drawing inferences about populations from samples
explanation: Using sample data and variability measures to make conclusions about the larger population.
